Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon microspindles templated from a metal–organic framework as highly selective and stable catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides Li Fang Investigation Methodology Writing - original draft 1 Qionghao Xu Investigation Methodology Writing - original draft 1 Yanyan Qi Methodology Xiaoxue Wu Methodology Yanghe Fu Writing - original draft Qiang Xiao Writing - original draft Fumin Zhang Conceptualization Project administration Supervision Writing - review & editing * Weidong Zhu Project administration Supervision Writing - review & editing * Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, 321004 Jinhua, People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, 321004 Jinhua, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract The preparation of efficient and recyclable solid catalysts exhibiting high activity and selectivity toward the target product is a prerequisite to enhance the overall efficiency of a catalytic process. Herein, we study a series of Fe/Fe3C-containing nitrogen-doped porous carbon microspindles (Fe/Fe3C@NC–x, where x stands for the pyrolysis temperature), which are core-/shell-structured hybrids, constructed by the pyrolysis of a metal–organic framework precursor as highly selective catalysts for the oxidation of sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxides under mild conditions. The Fe/Fe3C@NC–x microspindles comprising Fe and Fe3C nanocrystals inlaid in nitrogen-doped porous carbon shells are fabricated by the direct carbonization of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) polyhedra at 500 °C–800 °C and under nitrogen atmosphere. Among the various investigated catalysts, the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles exhibit the best catalytic activity, higher than those exhibited by the analogue Fe/Fe3C@C–600 without N doping and the commercial Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and Fe3C used for the catalytic oxidation of sulfides owing to the synergistic contribution of the Fe3C sites and adequate nitrogen doping in the porous carbon support. Furthermore, the magnetically separable properties of the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles enable their convenient isolation from the reaction system using an external magnet, and they can be repeatedly used for six cycles without any loss in catalytic efficiency. Keywords Metal–organic framework Fe/Fe3C@NC Nitrogen-doped porous carbon Selective oxidation Highly reusable catalyst 1 Introduction The catalytic oxidation of sulfides to their corresponding sulfoxides is an important class of reaction in organic synthesis [1]. Further, the transformation of sulfide that exhibits high activity and selectivity is particularly attractive for synthesizing various value-added intermediates, which are considerably important for the production of fine chemicals, biologically active compounds, and pharmaceutical auxiliaries [2]. These oxidations are conventionally catalyzed using stoichiometric amounts of heavy metal regents, such as Cr and Mn salts, which are environmentally unfriendly and generate a massive amount of harmful waste products [3,4]. Furthermore, the over-oxidation of sulfoxides to sulfones is an inevitable issue associated with the homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, several studies have investigated the usage of heterogeneous catalysts to improve the process efficiency and selectivity [5–19]. Among the investigated catalysts, the iron-based catalysts are promising alternatives because of their low toxicity, high abundance, and environmentally benign characteristics, which can be utilized in selective catalytic oxidations [16,6–19]. Another advantage of the iron-based catalysts is the ease of recovery from a liquid-phase system using an external magnet because of their magnetically recyclable properties [16]. For example, the iron oxide nanoparticles supported on SBA–15 have been reported as a magnetically recoverable catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of sulfides into sulfoxides in the aqueous phase [19]. However, the catalytic activity of the supported Fe2O3 catalyst is relatively low, and the inevitable deactivation occurred when the catalyst was used repeatedly. Therefore, it is still a challenge to develop highly efficient and recyclable transition metal catalysts to enhance the process efficiency of sulfide oxidation. The metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that are constructed by metal ions/clusters and organic ligands have displayed rapid development during the previous two decades because of their fascinating physicochemical properties [20–23]. Furthermore, based on a simple carbonization treatment, MOFs as sacrificial templates can be simultaneously converted into inorganic nanoparticles and carbon complex materials [24–26], in which the tiny metal and/or metal oxide nanoparticles may be uniformly dispersed throughout the porous carbon matrix. Thus, various hybrids exhibiting several different compositions and structures have been created [24–51]. For instance, the magnetic Fe3O4@C octahedra were fabricated using MIL–88B as the precursor and were observed to be highly active during the oxidation of alcohols in neat water [45]; a hybrid catalyst comprising nitrogen-doped Fe/Fe3C@C nanoboxes supported on reduced graphene oxide sheets was prepared by one-step carbonization of graphene oxide and the Prussian blue nanocubes, which exhibited high ORR activity and durability [46]. Porous ZnO/ZnFe2O4/C octahedra were manufactured by the carbonization of the Fe-modified MOF–5 as templates and exhibited good performance in high-rate lithium ion batteries [47]. Based on these achievements, the MOF-templated porous hybrids, exhibiting large specific surface area, highly dispersed heteroatoms, and controllable porous structure, can be considered to be promising candidates for various applications, especially for heterogeneous catalysis. Herein, we report the construction of core-/shell-structured Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon (Fe/Fe3C@NC) microspindles via a simple pyrolysis mechanism using the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) polyhedra as a sacrificial template. NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) is a typical MOF synthesized by the supramolecular assembly of iron clusters with amino terephthalic acids [52]. It may be an effective strategy to construct the core/shell structure of Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids by coupling the Fe-based active sites and N-doped porous carbon with defects in terms of the aforementioned advantages of the MOFs-derived catalysts. Furthermore, a strong interaction would occur between the metal nanoparticles and the N species derived from the amine groups tethered within the MOF frameworks upon high-temperature annealing, which are likely to strongly influence the surface electronic properties of the active sites [49]. Therefore, the hybrids are anticipated to exhibit high catalytic activity, excellent selectivity, and durability during the oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides. The excellent catalytic performance is likely caused by the joint contribution of the Fe3C sites and an adequate amount of N doping in the porous carbon support. To the best of our knowledge, this is an initial report on the fabrication of Fe/Fe3C@NC catalysts for the selective oxidation of sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxides. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 99 %), acetonitrile (CH3CN, >99 %), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 70 % in H2O), methyl phenyl sulfide (99 %), ethyl phenyl sulfide (99 %), methyl p-tolyl sulfide (99 %), diphenyl sulfide (99 %), 1,4-benzoquinone (99 %), and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO, 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF; ≥99.5 %), acetic acid (≥99.5 %), methanol (≥99.5 %), acetone (≥99.5 %), sulfuric acid (98 %), nitric acid (65.0–68.0 %), and isopropanol were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Terephthalic acid (BDC; >99 %) and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (NH2–BDC; >99 %) were obtained from TCI. All the commercial chemicals were used without performing any further purification. 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Philips PW3040/60 diffractometer for identifying the crystal phase and composition of the samples with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154 nm) in a 2-theta range of 5°–80°. The simulated XRD pattern of MIL–88B(Fe) was obtained from the reported single-crystal data using the Mercury program. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained at −196 °C and up to 1 bar on the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.). Before conducting the measurement, the sample was degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 16 h; subsequently, the specific surface areas were calculated according to the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller method in the relative pressure range of P/P0 = 0.05–0.25. The pore size curves were determined based on the adsorption isotherms using the density functional theory method, and the pore volume (V micro) was determined using the t plot method. The sample morphologies were analyzed using the Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) apparatus with an accelerating voltage ranging from 3 to 5 keV. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy elemental mapping analyses were conducted to verify the presence and distribution of the Fe, C, and N species. Subsequently, the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using the JEM2100 F apparatus at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV, and the samples were deposited on a hole-filled carbon film on a 300-mesh copper grid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Thermo VG ESCALAB250 using an Al Kα radiation of 300 W. The base pressure was approximately 3 × 10−9 mbar, and the binding energies were referenced with respect to the C1 s line of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Raman spectroscopy was performed on the InVia–Renishaw instrument with the laser source at 532 nm. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the STA-449C instrument (Netzsch) under flowing air (40 mL/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min at temperatures of 30 °C – 900 °C. Magnetic measurements were performed using a vibrating sample magnetometer (Lakeshore’s Model 7404) at room temperature (25 °C). 2.3 Catalyst preparation 2.3.1 NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) The NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microcrystals were synthesized using the solvothermal method [45]. FeCl3·6H2O (0.748 g, 2.76 mmol), NH2–BDC (0.502 g, 2.76 mmol), and acetic acid (6 mL) were added to DMF (60 mL) with stirring to obtain a clear brown solution. After stirring for an additional 50 min at 25 °C, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL) and heated to 125 °C for 24 h under static state conditions. The resulting brown solids were collected via centrifugation, washed, and purified using DMF and methanol, followed by drying at 120 °C for 16 h before use. MIL–88B(Fe) was synthesized using the same method as that for the preparation of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe); however, in this case, BDC was used as the organic ligand. 2.3.2 Fe/Fe3C@NC The Fe/Fe3C@NC microspindles were directly fabricated using a high-temperature thermal transformation treatment method. A ceramic boat containing NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microcrystals (1.0 g) was transferred into a tube furnace that was heated to the desired temperature at a rate of 3 °C/min under N gas flow (flow rate: 80 mL/min) and maintained at this temperature for 3 h. The boat was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, after which the black powders were collected (hereafter denoted as Fe/Fe3C@NC–x, where x represents the pyrolysis temperature from 500 °C–800 °C). Fe/Fe3C@C–600 without N doping was prepared using the same procedure. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The catalytic oxidation of sulfide was conducted in a Schlenk tube (10 mL). In a typical reaction, sulfide (1 mmol), CH3CN (3 mL), and catalyst (5 mg) were added to the tube. The reaction was set to start upon the addition of TBHP (3 mmol) at the typical reaction temperature (40 °C) under vigorous stirring. The liquid samples were withdrawn and analyzed on a gas chromatograph (Agilent GC-7890B) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (DB-5, 30 m ×0.45 mm ×0.42 μm) at certain reaction intervals using toluene as the internal standard. To minimize accidental experimental errors, all experiments were repeated three times and the error bars were within ±3% for all tests. For the recyclability test, the used Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 °C was separated and recovered using an external magnet, washed using acetone five times, dried at 150 °C, and subjected to the subsequent reaction cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The Fe/Fe3C@NC–x fabrication procedure is illustrated in Fig. 1 . First, highly uniform NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) hexagonal microspindles were synthesized using a solvothermal method. Subsequently, the obtained NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microcrystals were carbonized at high temperatures under nitrogen flow. During this annealing procedure, the parent NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microspindles gradually decomposed along with the release of unstable carbon-based species and the reduction of Fe3–μ3–oxo clusters to metal Fe, which subsequently evolved into a porous structure. Simultaneously, the formed metal Fe atoms reacted with the carbon species to yield Fe3C nanoparticles. The nitrogen and carbon species in the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) precursor yielded nitrogen-doped carbon layers on the surface of the generated Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles, creating an in-situ core-/shell-structured Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon (Fe/Fe3C@NC–x) hybrid. Interestingly, the polyhedral morphology of the precursor was appropriately inherited by the derived Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids. The crystal structure and phase composition of the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) precursor and its derived hybrids were analyzed using XRD. The results denoted that the XRD patterns of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) were completely consistent with the simulated patterns of MIL–88B(Fe) from the crystal data (Fig. S1, see Supporting Information) [52], confirming the successful synthesis of the precursor. Upon annealing, all the derived hybrids displayed a weak peak at a 2-theta of approximately 26.2° that can be attributed to the partially graphitized carbon (002) plane (Fig. 2 B) [46], revealing the formation of graphitic structure during the carbonization process. Additionally, for samples Fe/Fe3C@NC–600, Fe/Fe3C@NC–700, and Fe/Fe3C@NC–800, the other diffraction peaks are well-associated with those of α-Fe (JCPDS, No. 85-1317), and Fe3C species (JCPDS No. 87–0722) [42,43], respectively. In contrast, Fe3O4, as a major Fe species, was distinguished and determined for Fe/Fe3C@NC–500, with the results showing that the sample was not completely carbonized at 500 °C. Upon pyrolyzing at 600 °C – 800 °C, the Fe nanoclusters were formed by the reduction of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) catalyzed by the growth of N-doped porous carbon layers on the outer surface of Fe, whereas parts of carbon simultaneously reacted with Fe to generate Fe3C nanocrystallines, leading to the core-/shell-structured Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrid [47]. Briefly, the XRD results demonstrated that the pyrolysis temperature significantly influenced the phase composition of the derived composites and that the Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids with embedded Fe/Fe3C nanocrystals could be easily fabricated by directly annealing the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microspindles at 600 °C–800 °C in an inert atmosphere. Furthermore, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the various Fe/Fe3C@NC–x samples are presented in Fig. 3 A. Except Fe/Fe3C@NC–500, all the hybrids exhibit a type-IV isothermal curve along with an H3 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure range of 0.45–1.0, indicating that these Fe/Fe3C@NC–x possess hierarchical pore structures, which can be verified based on the corresponding pore size distribution curves (Fig. 3B). The predominant micropore sizes of these Fe/Fe3C@NC–x samples were centered at approximately 0.85 and 1.18 nm. Furthermore, the hybrid exhibits typical mesopore sizes centered at approximately 2.8 and 6.1 nm along with a certain amount of macropores. In contrast, Fe/Fe3C@NC–500 exhibited a limited amount of nitrogen adsorption and negligible hysteresis loop. The results from the N2 adsorption implies that the pyrolysis temperature is important to tune the specific surface area and pore volume of the derived hybrid: relatively low pyrolysis temperatures make it difficult to create pores, whereas too high of a pyrolysis temperature likely results in the collapse of the mesopores. Among these samples, Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 possessed the highest specific surface area (207 m2/g) and largest pore volume (0.22 cm3/g) (Table S1, see Supporting Information). The hierarchical porous structure and abundant composition of Fe/Fe3C@NC were mainly derived from the vaporization of unstable species in NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) during the high-temperature carbonization process. The large specific surface area and high pore volume of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 that are likely to ensure the accessibility of more active sites are beneficial for boosting the catalytic activity [43]. The chemical composition and bonding configuration of the derived Fe/Fe3C@NC–x samples were evaluated via XPS. The survey XPS spectrum of the hybrids verified the presence of C, O, N, and Fe (Figs. S2A–S5A). The high-resolution C 1s spectra of all samples could be fitted using three characteristic peaks centered at 284.8 ± 0.1, 285.7 ± 0.1, and 288.3 ± 0.2 eV, which were correlated with CC, CN, and CO species, respectively (Figs. S2B and S5B). The high-resolution Fe 2p spectra of all hybrids exhibited two prominent peaks at 711.1 and 724.7 eV that were assigned to Fe3C (Fig. 4 A) [42,43] in accordance with the XRD analysis. Strangely, the XPS signals could not be observed for the metal Fe nanoparticles. One reasonable explanation is that the metal Fe species were wrapped by the porous carbon layers; therefore, they could not be evaluated using XPS because of the limited detection depth of this technology. This was further confirmed by the difference between the Fe content in Fe/Fe3C@NC determined by XPS (approximately 1.5 %) and that determined by TGA analysis (approximately 33.5 %–61.1 %) (Fig. S7). Furthermore, the high-resolution N 1s spectra of the Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids were analyzed and could be deconvoluted into four components exhibiting binding energies of 398.5 ± 0.1, 399.7 ± 0.1, 401.1 ± 0.1, and 402.9 ± 0.1 eV (Fig. 4B), which represent pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and N-oxidized species [42–46], respectively, confirming that nitrogen was still doped in the hybrids after high-temperature annealing. The content of the different N species in each sample could be achieved in terms of the peak areas, and the data are listed in Table S1 (the Supporting Information). Apparently, the pyrolysis treatments at elevated temperatures (500 °C – 800 °C) caused a significant decrease in the total N content. In addition, upon increasing the carbonization temperature, the content of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N decreased significantly, implying that the thermal stabilities of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N were relatively lower than that of graphitic N. Notably, pyridinic and pyrrolic N are likely to interaction with metal moieties (such as Fe), and the coexistence of pyridinic N and graphitic N are believed to be beneficial for catalysis [53]. The Raman spectra of all the Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids exhibited a high ratio of G-band to D-band intensities (Fig. 5 ) and a broad two-dimensional (2D) peak at approximately 2800 cm−1 occurred for samples Fe/Fe3C@NC–700 and Fe/Fe3C@NC–800, indicating that some few-layered graphene-like architecture was present in these two samples [43]. Furthermore, as mentioned above, the carbon species in Fe/Fe3C@NC–x were solely derived from the ligand of the MOF precursor (NH2–BDC). The strong D-band intensity in the Raman spectra suggests that these carbon-based hybrids include defects induced by the heteroatom nitrogen, which may play a significant role in enhancing the catalytic activity because of changes in the local electronic structures and chemical properties of the carbon materials [53]. The typical magnetization curves of Fe/Fe3C@NC–x samples as a function of the applied field are displayed in Fig. 6 . As shown in Fig. 6, all the samples exhibited superparamagnetic behavior and little hysteresis. Notably, the saturation magnetization of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 was measured to be 123 emu/g, although it was lower than that of bulk Fe3C (169 emu/g) [54] but much higher than its counterparts (24.1 emu/g for Fe/Fe3C@NC–500, 95.9 emu/g for Fe/Fe3C@NC–700, and 97.7 emu/g for Fe/Fe3C@NC–800). Consequently, the strong magnetism of the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles allows them to be easily and efficiently separated from the heterogeneous systems, facilitating catalyst recycling and repeated usage. The SEM images reveal that the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) precursor comprises well-dispersed microspindle crystals exhibiting lengths of approximately 2 μm and diameters of 1 μm (Fig. S7, Supporting Information) [52]. After performing thermal treatment at a high temperature, the NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) microspindles were converted into porous Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids. The derived Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 almost retained the original polyhedral structure of the MOF precursor even though its size slightly decreased because of the decomposition and shrinkage of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) during annealing (Fig. 7 A–C). The corresponding EDX elemental mapping analysis of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 revealed the high distribution of all the C, Fe, and N elements in the hybrid (Fig. 7D–F). The morphologies of the other derived samples were very similar to that of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 (Fig. S8, Supporting Information). The TEM images denoted that the sizes of the derived Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles reduced when compared with those of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) (Fig. 8 A–B). Each individual microspindle was inlaid with many Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles with sizes of mainly 20–30 nm (Fig. S9, Supporting Information). Closer observations revealed that the Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles were entirely wrapped by the continuous carbon layers exhibiting a thickness of approximately 14 nm, forming Fe/Fe3C@NC core-/shell-structured nanoparticles (yellow rectangle of Fig. 8C). The high-resolution TEM image of the dark core displayed clear lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.24 nm (Fig. 8D), which matched well with the (210) plane of Fe3C [42]. External carbon shells could prevent the agglomeration and leaching of the embedded Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles, enabling Fe/Fe3C@NC to demonstrate excellent recyclability when used in liquid reactions. 3.2 Selective oxidation of sulfides Inspired by the excellent physicochemical properties of the prepared Fe/Fe3C@NC–x hybrids, such as the porous core/shell structure, large specific surface area, and unique composition, we evaluated their catalytic properties in the selective oxidation of sulfides using TBHP as the oxidizing agent. First, methyl phenyl sulfide as the model substrate was initially used as the reactant to compare the catalytic activities of different catalysts (Fig. 9 ). When the reaction was performed in a blank experiment (without the addition of any catalyst), almost no conversion could be detected by GC analysis, suggesting the requirement of a catalyst for oxidation. In the presence of either Fe3O4 or Fe(acca)3, no significant amount of product could be produced. Fe(acca)3 can be completely dissolved in the reaction medium, causing difficulty in catalyst recovery and recycling. Furthermore, when solid Fe2O3 was selected as the reference, only 36 % of methyl phenyl sulfide could be converted, with a selectivity of 98.5 % being observed for methyl phenyl sulfoxide. The control catalyst Fe/Fe3C@C–600 (the analogue without N doping and in which the Fe species existed as Fe3O4; Fig. S10) exhibited very limited catalytic activity; however, when Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 was used as a catalyst, the quantity of converted methyl phenyl sulfide (72 %) was doubled relative to that of Fe2O3 with ultrahigh selectivity (99.1 %) for methyl phenyl sulfoxide and greater than those of the commercial Fe3C (57.8 %) and ferrous powder (<2%, not shown). Not surprisingly, Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 displayed optimal activity among the derived samples (Fig. S11). Based on these comparisons, the high catalytic activity of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 is likely due to the synergistic effect of the intrinsic activity of Fe3C sites as well as an adequate amount N doping in the porous carbon networks. To illustrate the influence of the Fe-containing sites in the catalytic oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide, we performed an acid leaching experiment on Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 (see detail in Supporting Information). The acid-treated sample was characterized via XRD, N2 adsorption, and XPS analyses. No Fe or Fe3C species were detected in the XRD patterns of the acid-treated Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 sample (denoted as Fe/Fe3C@NC–600–A), whereas the peaks from carbon species became more pronounced (Fig. S12). Additionally, the specific surface area of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600–A increased by 60 % when compared with that of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 (Fig. S13 and Table S1), and high-resolution XPS spectrum revealed no Fe species, suggesting the complete removal of Fe, at least from the surface layer, whereas the total N content was not affected by the treatment (Fig. S14 and Table S2). When Fe/Fe3C@NC–600–A was used as a catalyst, it exhibited a much lower activity relative to that of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 (Fig. S15). Because commercial Fe3C exhibited substantial catalytic activity and ferrous powder was inert to oxidation, the results suggest that the loss in activity of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600–A can be mainly attributed to the removal of the Fe3C sites. However, because the activity of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600–A was higher than that of Fe/Fe3C@C–600 (the analogue without N doping), the contribution of N doping to the porous carbon support could not be excluded. Therefore, these findings infer that the synergistic contribution of the Fe3C nanoparticles and adequate N doping in the porous carbon were responsible for the high catalytic performance of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600. The influences of reaction parameters (temperature, time, and molar ratio of the substrate to TBHP) on the catalytic activity and selectivity were considered using Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 as the representative catalyst to determine the optimal reaction conditions in the present system. As illustrated in Fig. 10 , the sulfide conversion was 33.6 % when the temperature was 20 °C; the sulfide conversion reached 72 % when the reaction temperature was increased up to 40 °C. As the reaction temperature was further increased, the conversion only slightly increased. The selectivities of methyl phenyl sulfoxide were greater than 99 % over Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 in the reaction temperature range considered in this study. Fig. 11 denotes the effect of the molar ratio of methyl phenyl sulfide to TBHP on the conversion and selectivity of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 in the catalytic oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide. The conversion increased with an increase in the molar ratio, and the maximum conversion of 72 % was observed at a methyl phenyl sulfide to TBHP molar ratio of 1:3. Only a moderate increase was observed in the conversion of methyl phenyl sulfide by any further increase in the molar ratio. Fig. 12 shows the conversion of methyl phenyl sulfide and the selectivity for methyl phenyl sulfoxide as a function of the reaction time in the selective oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide. In case of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600, the conversion of methyl phenyl sulfide continuously increased up to 72 % within the reaction duration of 12 h and then increased slightly when the reaction duration was prolonged to 24 h. A hot-filtration experiment was also performed during the catalytic test process to verify the heterogeneous nature of the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 hybrid. Thus, the catalyst was quickly separated from the reaction mixture using an external magnet once the reaction had proceeded for 6 h (see the inset subfigure in Fig. 6). The corresponding conversion of methyl phenyl sulfide as a function of the reaction time is plotted in Fig. 12. The subsequent conversion showed no significant increase, revealing the termination of the reaction by the elimination of the catalyst. The hot-filtration test simply but effectively excluded the potential leaching problem of active species from the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 catalyst. ICP-AES analysis of the reaction liquor confirmed that the content of Fe species in the solution was under the detection limit, revealing that no significant leaching of the active Fe/Fe3C occurred during the reaction process. Further, we examined the recycling properties of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 to demonstrate the recyclability of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600. As shown in Fig. 13 , the catalytic activity and selectivity were well maintained during six consecutive runs. The recovered catalysts were further evaluated using XRD and TEM, denoting no obvious differences in the crystal structure or particle size and distribution of the Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles when compared with those of the fresh catalyst (Figs. S16 and S17, Supporting Information). Thus, we can confirm that the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 catalyst exhibits excellent stability under the given catalytic conditions. During the catalytic oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide using TBHP as the oxidant, the reactions may proceed via a free radical mechanism. To clarify this assumption, radical scavengers, including isopropanol (scavenger for hydroxyl radicals), 1,4-benzoquinone (scavenger for superoxide radicals), and/or DMPO (radical trapping reagent for various radicals), were added into the reaction mixture to investigate their effects on the catalytic performance of Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 during the oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide (Table 1 ). Clearly, a significant decrease in activity or even deactivation occurred in the presence of any of these scavengers, confirming that selective oxidation may be involved in the free radical mechanism. The catalytic oxidation of the remaining sulfides while using Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 is summarized in Table S3. Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 exhibited good catalytic oxidation activity for ethyl phenyl sulfide and methyl p-tolyl sulfide. However, Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 exhibited very limited catalytic oxidation activity for diphenyl sulfide. This is probably due to the bulkiness of the diphenyl sulfide molecule, which would make activation difficult under the investigated reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, we developed a series of magnetically recyclable core-/shell-structured Fe/Fe3C@N-doped carbon hybrids via the facile pyrolysis of a Fe-based MOF, NH2–MIL–88(B)–Fe, for the selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides. Fe/Fe3C nanoparticles (with sizes mainly in the 20–30 nm range) were well inlaid within the N-doped porous carbon matrix, effectively limiting the aggregation and growth of the metal nanoparticles and promoting the mass transfer of the reactants. These transition metal-based hybrids exhibit highly efficient and stable catalytic performances in terms of oxidation of several sulfides into their corresponding sulfoxides. Moreover, the developed Fe/Fe3C@NC hybrids were conveniently recovered using an external magnet and could be reused at least six times without any loss in efficiency. The acid leaching experiment demonstrated the key role of the Fe3C sites with respect to the catalytic oxidation of sulfides. coredata.dc:description: The preparation of efficient and recyclable solid catalysts exhibiting high activity and selectivity toward the target product is a prerequisite to enhance the overall efficiency of a catalytic process. Herein, we study a series of Fe/Fe3C-containing nitrogen-doped porous carbon microspindles (Fe/Fe3C@NC–x, where x stands for the pyrolysis temperature), which are core-/shell-structured hybrids, constructed by the pyrolysis of a metal–organic framework precursor as highly selective catalysts for the oxidation of sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxides under mild conditions. The Fe/Fe3C@NC–x microspindles comprising Fe and Fe3C nanocrystals inlaid in nitrogen-doped porous carbon shells are fabricated by the direct carbonization of NH2–MIL–88B(Fe) polyhedra at 500 °C–800 °C and under nitrogen atmosphere. Among the various investigated catalysts, the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles exhibit the best catalytic activity, higher than those exhibited by the analogue Fe/Fe3C@C–600 without N doping and the commercial Fe2O3, Fe3O4, and Fe3C used for the catalytic oxidation of sulfides owing to the synergistic contribution of the Fe3C sites and adequate nitrogen doping in the porous carbon support. Furthermore, the magnetically separable properties of the Fe/Fe3C@NC–600 microspindles enable their convenient isolation from the reaction system using an external magnet, and they can be repeatedly used for six cycles without any loss in catalytic efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Fe/Fe3C@N-doped porous carbon microspindles templated from a metal–organic framework as highly selective and stable catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides
